Seventeenth century and earlier[edit]

This section needs expansion. You can help by adding to it. (June 2008)
  • 44 BC – Assassination of Julius Caesar (Rome, Roman Republic). During Caesar's cremation in the Forum, an incensed mob took firebrands from the pyre and attacked the houses of Brutus and Cassius, as well as killing Helvius Cinna.[citation needed]
  • 40 – Riots erupted in Alexandria (Roman Egypt) between Jews and Greeks.
  • 532 – Nika riots (Constantinople, Byzantine Empire). 30,000 killed in the Hippodrome.[1]
  • 1046 – Vata pagan uprising (Pest, Hungary)
  • 1182 – (Constantinople, Byzantine Empire). Venetians and other "Latins" massacred during a riot.[citation needed]
  • 1229 – University of Paris strike of 1229 (Paris, France). Student riot leads to closing of university for two years.
  • 1355 – St Scholastica Day riot (Oxford, England)
  • 1517 – Evil May Day (London, England)
  • 1572 – St. Bartholomew's Day massacre (Paris, France)
  • 1648 – Salt Riot (Moscow, Russia)
  • 1662 – Copper Riot (Moscow, Russia)
  • 1668 – Bawdy House Riots (London, England)
  • 1692 – Mexico City [2]

  • 2012 – Riots in Qatif, Saudi Arabia, 1 killed and at least 6 injured.[324]
  • 2012 – Riots in Chilaw, Sri Lanka, 1 killed and 4 injured.[325]
  • 2012 – Riots in Apodaca, Nuevo León, Mexico, 44 killed in a prison riot.[326]
  • 2012 – Riots in Rustenburg, South Africa, 2 killed.[327]
  • 2012 – Riots in Afghanistan, 23 killed.[328][329][330]
  • 2012 – Riots in Songea, Tanzania, 2 killed.[331]
  • 2012 – Riots in Aysén, Chile, 1 killed and several injured.[332]
  • 2012 – Riots in Macedonia, 2 killed and dozens wounded.[333]
  • 2012 – Riots in Puerto Maldonado, Peru, 3 killed and more than 30 injured.[334]
  • 2012 – Riots in Turkey, 1 killed.[335]
  • 2012 – Riots in Port Said, Egypt, 1 killed and 65 injured.[336]
  • 2012 – Riots in Israel, West Bank and Gaza, 1 killed and scores injured.[337]
  • 2012 – Riots in San Pedro Sula, Honduras, at least 18 killed.[338]
  • 2012 – Riots in Gilgit–Baltistan, Pakistan, at least 17 killed and nearly 50 injured.[339]
  • 2012 – Riot in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, 25000 protesters fired upon by police using water cannons and tear gas.[340]
  • 2012 – Riots in Cairo, Egypt, at least 20 killed.[341]
  • 2012 – Riots in Tunis, Tunisia, 1 killed.[342]
  • 2012 – Riots in Papua Province, Indonesia, 1 killed and 4 injured.[343]
  • 2012 – Riots in Rakhine State, Myanmar, 50 killed.[344][345]

  • 2012 – Riots in Delhi, India, 1 killed and more than 85 injured.[350]
  • 2012 – Riots in Linden, Guyana, at least 3 killed.[351]
  • 2012 – Riots in Mérida state, Venezuela, at least 22 killed.[352]
  • 2012 – Riots in Assam, India, at least 36 killed.[353]
  • 2012 – Riots in Anaheim, California, several injuries and 24 arrested.[354]
  • 2012 – Riots in Nyala, Sudan, 6 killed.[355]
  • 2012 – Riots in Zogota, Guinea, 5 killed.[356]

  • 2012 – Project X Haren in Haren, Groningen, the Netherlands. Over 30 injured.[360][361]

  • 2012 - Rioting during the Belfast City Hall flag protests in Northern Ireland.[363]

2013[edit]

  • 2013 - Riots in Belfast, Northern Ireland during the flag protests. 29 police officers were hurt.[364]
  • 2013 – 2013 Bulgarian protests
  • 2013 – Riots in Stockholm, Sweden
  • 2013 – Riots in Bangladesh [365]
  • 2013 – Riots in Turkey (Istanbul) [366]
  • 2013 – Riots in Brazil (São Paulo, Brasilia, Rio de Janeiro, Belo Horizonte, Salvador, Recife, Curitiba, Porto Alegre and Vitória) [367]
  • 2013 – Riots in Belfast, Northern Ireland following July 12 parade and over several days. Dozens injured mainly Police Officers.[368]
  • 2013 – Riots in Shanshan County (Xinjiang, China) 27 people were killed in riots.[369]
  • 2013 – Riots in Huntington Beach, California, 1 injured.[370][371]
  • 2013 – Riots in Cape Town, South Africa [372][373][374]
  • 2013 – Riots in Belfast, Northern Ireland on 9 August.
  • 2013 – Riots in Singapore, 18 injured.[375]

2014[edit]

Tear gas being used against opposition protesters in Altamira, Caracas during the 2014 Venezuelan protests
  • 2014 – Euromaidan in Ukraine, from 21 November 2013 – 23 February 2014. Protests and riots in Kiev, Ukraine (106 dead, 1,880 injured, 1,340 hospitalized, 320 arrested for mass rioting and 125+ police officers injured).[376][377]
  • 2014 – Hrushevskoho Street riots, from 19 Jan 2014 – 23 February 2014. Kiev, Ukraine
  • 2014 – 20 January Haredi rioted Brooklyn[citation needed]
  • 2014 – February–May 2014: 2014 Venezuelan protests, 43 killed, 5000+ injured, 3,689 arrested.
  • 2014 – Riots in Mombasa, Kenya after a raid on a mosque by police.[378]
  • 2014 – 2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina The 2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina is a series of demonstrations and riots that began in the northern town of Tuzla on 4 February 2014, but quickly spread to multiple cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar.[379]
  • 2014 – Zhengzhou Airport riot, 5–6 February in China.[380]
  • 2014 – Riots in Tampa, Florida After Cigar City Brewing Company prematurely ran out of beer at their annual release of their highly acclaimed Hunahpu's Imperial Stout, angry attendees began a small riot. Police were called to the scene and dispersed the angry crowd. The riot prompted the brewery's owners to cancel the event in the future. No lives were lost, but some injuries were reported.[381]
  • 2014 – Riots in Mexico caused by the 2014 Iguala mass kidnapping [382]
  • 2014 – Riots in Ferguson, Missouri caused by the shooting of Michael Brown and charges against the accused officer being dropped.[383]
2015 Baltimore protests following the death of Freddie Gray

2015[edit]

  • April 26: 2015 Baltimore riots erupted in Baltimore, Maryland, United States in response to the death of 25-year-old Freddie Gray, who died while in police custody.
  • July: Three days of riots in Belfast, Northern Ireland following the July 12 parade.[384]
  • December: 2015 Corsican protests follow the rise of Corsican nationalism and resulted in the burning of a mosque in Ajaccio and continuing protests.

2016[edit]

  • February: 2016 Mong Kok civil unrest (Mong Kok, Hong Kong)
  • February 27: Riots after the shooting of Abdi Mohamed in Salt Lake City, Utah, U.S.
  • March 13: Riot in Melbourne, Australia CBD largely Gang-Affiliated Gunshots were reported in the night.[385]
  • May–June: A series of violent riots Melbourne, Australia between pro and anti-Islam protesters result in numerous injuries and arrests.[386][387]
  • May 25: Protesters outside a Trump rally rioted in Albuquerque, New Mexico, injuring several police officers[388]
  • June 2: San Jose, California, Trump rally turns violent when protesters attacked supporters and one Police Officer was assaulted[389]
  • June 10-19: UEFA Euro 2016 riots throughout France.
  • August: 2016 Milwaukee riots
  • August 30: Riots break out in Kalgoorlie, Australia after the Death of Elijah Doughty. 12 police officers injured and buildings and cars damaged.[390]
  • September: Kaveri River water dispute#2016
  • September: Riots in Charlotte, North Carolina caused by the shooting of Keith Lamont Scott by a police officer.[citation needed]
  • November: Protests in many major United States cities over the election of Donald Trump as president of the United States. Many protests lead to riots in various cities. Riots in Portland, Oregon resulted in at least 100 people arrested, and four people injured. (Citation needed for other cities beyond Portland.)
Millions protesting during the Mother of All Marches, part of the 2017 Venezuelan protests

2017[edit]

  • January 20: Sporadic rioting by anarchists in Washington D.C. during the Inauguration of Donald Trump, Leading to 234 arrests for rioting, and 6 officers needing medical attention.
  • February 20: Rinkeby riots in Sweden.
  • February 27–March 2: Dhaka, Bangladesh Transport Workers Riots.[391] Transport workers paralyze the city in protest against a court verdict of a fellow worker, clashing with police, causing arson attack, torching of vehicles and other violence. Most violence were reported at the Gabtoli Intersection. One worker was killed after police forced to open fire.
  • 4–15 February and 27–28 March: 2017 French riots
  • 31 March 2017—12 August 2017: 2017 Venezuelan protests, 165 killed, 15000+ injured, 4848 arrested.
  • 7 August: Rioting in Belfast, Northern Ireland.[392]
  • 25-26 August: 2017 Northern India riots, following the rape conviction of Sikh religious leader Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh. 40+ people killed in violence by his followers.
  • November 29–December 10: Tegucigalpa, Honduras After a close election between Salvador Nasralla and Juan Orlando Hernandez the electoral body in Honduras still had no results days after the election, so protests against the government occurred, because the government was having reelection even though it is unconstitutional, at the beginning the opposition candidate Salvador Nasralla was winning by 5% but the system fell and 3 days after the reelecting president Juan Orlando Hernandez started to win, this led to protests all over the country which were repressed by the police that up to today are still occurring, until now there has been 34 deaths, between the riots the government declared curfew between 6 PM and 6 AM.

2018[edit]

  • 1 February: Calais Migrant Riot: Violence between two groups of migrants, 100 Eritreans and 30 Afghans in Calais, France.
  • 2 April: Rioting in Derry, Northern Ireland following an illegal republican march.[393]
  • 25 June: Riots in Nigeria between Muslim herders and Christian farmers. 86 dead.[394]
  • 04-06 August: Riots in Bangladesh following attacks by government supporters on students protesting against recent deaths deaths due to reckless driving in the country. Hardest hit was the Dhanmondi area in the capital which was reportedly turned into a total battlefield, though riots took place all over the country.[395][396][397][398][399]
